courseDescription: Designed in consultation with advisor to provide in-depth experience in a school or community setting in which to enact a guided project on a topic of interest.

The emphasis of this course is on the theoretical approaches to the social/emotional development of the child that include the psychodynamic, humanistic, cognitive, behavioral, and social learning models as applied to responsive practices that promote the healthy emotional wellbeing of children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of psychodynamic, humanistic, cognitive, behavioral, and social learning models
Application of theoretical approaches to child development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Responsive problem-solving to promote emotional wellbeing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in promoting healthy emotional development

courseTitle: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives on Education
courseDescription: The present educational system, its social impact and future implications are viewed in historical, philosophical, and sociological perspectives. Special attention is given to technology, research, multicultural education/equity and leadership.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing future implications of educational trends

courseTitle: Theoretical Perspectives in Curriculum and Instruction
courseDescription: This course introduces a range of theoretical perspectives and epistemologies in the field of curriculum and instruction.  Students will gain strategies for critical reading, scholarly writing, and identify areas for prospective inquiry.

Students will investigate a range of instructional theories and design theories in terms of learning domains and pedagogical approaches to the teaching/learning process in a variety of educational settings.  Students will utilize a systematic design process grounded in theories and research to propose/develop instruction for specific learning goals related to their own professional situations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of instruction for specific learning goals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Instruction development for specific learning goals

courseDescription: Explores the relationship between the historical, philosophical, and sociopolitical influence on curriculum development and evaluation.  Historical and cultural approaches to designing and implementing curricular models, curriculum reform, and understanding the politics of conceptualizing the curriculum process are highlighted. Major issues concerning educational curriculum reform are addressed and reviewed.

Investigates the role and nature of the curriculum for particular subject-matter specialties - e.g., math, social studies, science, English, school librarianship, reading, etc. Objectives are tailored to specific content areas.
Technical and Digital Skills: Subject-matter expertise in chosen specialty (e.g., math, social studies, science, English, school librarianship, reading, etc.)
Curriculum development for specific content areas
Use of educational technologies in curriculum development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Tailoring communication based on specific content areas
Collaboration with fellow educators and specialists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the role and nature of the curriculum for specific subjects
Identifying effective teaching strategies for specific content areas
Evaluating the effectiveness of curriculum objectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading curriculum development for specific content areas
Organizing curriculum objectives according to subject-matter needs
Coordinating with fellow educators and specialists in curriculum development

courseDescription: Explores various models of supervision and relates them to the administration and supervision of reading programs.  Also prepares the prospective administrator/supervisor to make decisions relative to the methods and materials used to teach reading.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of different methods and materials used to teach reading
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate decisions regarding teaching methods and materials
Cooperation and coordination in supervising reading programs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision-making for selecting teaching methods and materials
Analysis and evaluation of supervision models

courseDescription: This course is designed for teachers having completed the initial reading practicum.  Its focus is on the refinement and further exploration of ways to work with students experiencing reading difficulties.  Both group and individual tutoring experiences will be provided.  Ways will be explored to encourage involvement in existing educational programs and schools.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods for individual student needs

courseDescription: Directed study of current topics of interest to students involved in literacy research.  Topics to include emergent literacy assessment, adult literacy programs, and other areas of investigation.  Students will be required to prepare a scholarly paper reporting results for publication.

courseTitle: Instructional Technology Trends in Curriculum and Instruction
courseDescription: Examines selected issues and trends involving the use of technology in curriculum and instruction.  Students develop a critical awareness of contemporary technology, an understanding of current research regarding the successful implementation of technology in curriculum and instruction, and strategies for using new technology in the future.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of technology in curriculum and instruction
Strategies for using new technology in the future
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing research regarding successful technology implementation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing current research on technology implementation
Developing strategies for future technology use

courseDescription: This course will explore theoretical and methodological orientations towards conducting research with youth and adults. Students will focus on ethical, political, and pedagogical considerations that arise in employing participatory practices, explore methods for listening and representing participant voice, and consider implications for policy and practice

courseTitle: Reconceptualizing Theory and Practice for Work with Children and Families
courseDescription: This graduate seminar explores post-structural theories as they relate to understandings about young children, families, and education. The focus is on intersections of race, class, gender, and age as potential constructs of how thought and action are organized and the political, historical, and economic contexts that contribute to such discourses. Students will consider theory, research and practices in readings, discussions and class assignments.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulating intersections of race, class, gender, and age
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing political, historical, and economic contexts
Applying post-structural theories to real-life scenarios

courseDescription: This graduate seminar explores perspectives on early literacy that draw from sociocultural, postmodern, and post-structural theories. Viewing literacy as a social practice, students will explore children’s literacy with an emphasis on children’s agency and their roles as active producers of meaning. Students will be asked to critically examine early literacy research and practice to contribute to rich understandings of diverse learning needs across social, economic, and multilingual contexts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of early literacy research and practice
Understanding social and economic contexts of learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting educational practices to diverse contexts

courseTitle: Change Issues in Curriculum and Instruction
courseDescription: Explores questions and issues related to the evolving nature of curriculum and instruction and the design of the contemporary curriculum.  Through readings and projects, students will examine new discoveries in research and technology, the effect of these and other changes on education, and the challenges of life-long learning as an influence on change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of research and technology advancements in education
Curriculum design based on new technologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the effects of changes on education
Problem-solving for challenges of lifelong learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading change in curriculum and instruction
Organizing projects related to curriculum change

courseDescription: Explores topics related to the cultural characteristics of ethnically diverse populations and how these diverse populations and characteristics interact with social, political and economic institutions and the dominant culture to create the contemporary environment.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiating social, political, and economic differences

courseDescription: Provides opportunities for doctoral students to explore topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.
Hours to be arranged. Provides opportunities for the doctoral student to do independent research in an area of his/her particular interests and needs.

The emphasis of this course is on the theoretical approaches to the social/emotional development of the child that include the psychodynamic, humanistic, cognitive, behavioral, and social learning models as applied to responsive practices that promote the healthy emotional wellbeing of children.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Applying theoretical approaches in interaction with children
Understanding and responding to diverse emotional needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of child emotional wellbeing
Application of cognitive, behavioral, and social learning models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading responsive practices for child wellbeing
Organizing strategies based on theoretical models

courseTitle: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives on Education
courseDescription: The present educational system, its social impact and future implications are viewed in historical, philosophical, and sociological perspectives. Special attention is given to technology, research, multicultural education/equity and leadership.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of educational technology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating multicultural and equity issues in education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical, philosophical, and sociological perspectives on education
Evaluating implications of contemporary educational practices

courseTitle: Theoretical Perspectives in Curriculum and Instruction
courseDescription: This course introduces a range of theoretical perspectives and epistemologies in the field of curriculum and instruction.  Students will gain strategies for critical reading, scholarly writing, and identify areas for prospective inquiry.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of areas for prospective inquiry
Analysis and interpretation of curriculum theories

courseDescription: Students will investigate a range of instructional theories and design theories in terms of learning domains and pedagogical approaches to the teaching/learning process in a variety of educational settings.  Students will utilize a systematic design process grounded in theories and research to propose/develop instruction for specific learning goals related to their own professional situations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Aligning instruction with specific learning goals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Utilization of theories and research in design

courseDescription: Explores the relationship between the historical, philosophical, and sociopolitical influence on curriculum development and evaluation.  Historical and cultural approaches to designing and implementing curricular models, curriculum reform, and understanding the politics of conceptualizing the curriculum process are highlighted. Major issues concerning educational curriculum reform are addressed and reviewed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and explaining sociopolitical influences on curriculum
Communicating the importance of curriculum reform
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and cultural approaches to curriculum
Critically reviewing educational curriculum reform issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and conceptualizing the curriculum process

courseDescription: This course will establish a theoretical lens by which students will understand learning as socially and culturally constituted and apply this foundation to literacy acquisition and learning.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of sociocultural factors in learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing learning from a sociocultural perspective

courseDescription: This course will draw on sociocultural perspectives to provide an empirical, historical, and theoretical examination of issues that impact youth in societies characterized by structural inequalities. These inequalities may be based on class, race, ethnicity, and sexual/gendered relations of dominance and subordination. Exploration through various texts from several academic disciplines will enable course participants to analyze the intersection of education, social change, and youth development in the contexts of self-discovery, identity, culture, belonging, citizenship, participation, and activism.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing intersectionality in education and youth development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting active citizenship and youth participation

courseDescription: This course concentrates on the theoretical underpinnings of qualitative research, methodology and methods including identification of ways to collect and analyze qualitative data; examination of ethical issues; development of proposals; and writing up studies.

This advanced qualitative course is an introduction to emerging research approaches and alternative data collection methods and analyses in education, counseling and other related disciplines. Content addressed includes visual and audio research, historical movements in qualitative research, critical theory, feminism, queer theory, ethnomethodology, autoethnography, content analysis, and mixed methods research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Skills in using alternative data collection methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Historical analysis of qualitative research movements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating and implementing various research approaches

courseDescription: Directed study of current topics of interest to students involved in literacy research.  Topics to include emergent literacy assessment, adult literacy programs, and other areas of investigation.  Students will be required to prepare a scholarly paper reporting results for publication.

courseTitle: Instructional Technology Trends in Curriculum and Instruction
courseDescription: Examines selected issues and trends involving the use of technology in curriculum and instruction.  Students develop a critical awareness of contemporary technology, an understanding of current research regarding the successful implementation of technology in curriculum and instruction, and strategies for using new technology in the future.
Technical and Digital Skills: Strategies for using new technology in curriculum and instruction
Critical analysis of technology implementation in curriculum
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conveying strategies for implementing technology in curriculum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving with technology in curriculum and instruction
Analyzing current research on technology implementation in curriculum
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading technology implementation in curriculum and instruction
Organizing and planning for future technology use in curriculum

courseDescription: This course will explore theoretical and methodological orientations towards conducting research with youth and adults. Students will focus on ethical, political, and pedagogical considerations that arise in employing participatory practices, explore methods for listening and representing participant voice, and consider implications for policy and practice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative research with diverse groups (youth and adults)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing ethical and political issues in research

courseTitle: Reconceptualizing Theory and Practice for Work with Children and Families
courseDescription: This graduate seminar explores post-structural theories as they relate to understandings about young children, families, and education. The focus is on intersections of race, class, gender, and age as potential constructs of how thought and action are organized and the political, historical, and economic contexts that contribute to such discourses. Students will consider theory, research and practices in readings, discussions and class assignments.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Race, class, gender, and age sensitivity
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing intersections of race, class, gender, and age
Understanding political, historical, and economic contexts

courseDescription: This graduate seminar explores perspectives on early literacy that draw from sociocultural, postmodern, and post-structural theories. Viewing literacy as a social practice, students will explore children’s literacy with an emphasis on children’s agency and their roles as active producers of meaning. Students will be asked to critically examine early literacy research and practice to contribute to rich understandings of diverse learning needs across social, economic, and multilingual contexts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying sociocultural, postmodern, and post-structural theories to literacy
Understanding of diverse learning needs across social, economic, and multilingual contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating children’s agency in literacy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical examination of early literacy research and practice
Analyzing and interpreting children’s roles as active producers of meaning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on diverse learning needs

courseTitle: Concepts and Contexts in School Librarianship
courseDescription: Will introduce candidates to the broad landscape of school librarianship and its relationship to the greater library and information profession. Includes a critical examination of benchmarks and key concepts tied to literacies, information science, and technical innovation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to relate to the greater library and information profession
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the landscape of school librarianship

courseTitle: Ethnographic Research and Narrative & Historical Research Methods and Design
courseDescription: In this advanced qualitative research course, students will focus on ethnographic methods such as ethnography, ethnomethodology, and autoethnomethodology. Students will also learn about participatory research methods. The course will examine narrative and historical research approaches including biography and autobiography.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical and narrative texts
Identifying patterns and themes in ethnographic data

courseTitle: Critical and Indigenous Research Methods and Design
courseDescription: In this advanced qualitative methods course, students will explore readings related to critical and indigenous research, methodologies and paradigms as well as engage in activities to decolonize traditional research approaches with specific groups. This course refers to indigenous peoples as individuals and groups belonging to developing or underdeveloped regions nationally or internationally.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and presentation of research data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of traditional research methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing research activities for specific groups

courseDescription: This advanced qualitative research course examines emerging and lesser known qualitative research methods such as self-study, portraiture, arts-based research, photovoice, rhizomatic analysis and critical policy analysis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of lesser known qualitative research methods
Understanding and execution of portraiture research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective articulation of qualitative research findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of qualitative research outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination and leadership in research settings

courseTitle: Case Study, Grounded Theory, & Phenomenological Research Methods & Design
courseDescription: This advanced qualitative research course examines the intricacies of case study methods. It also delves into the various qualitative research methods surrounding experience and theory formation such as Grounded Theory, Phenomenology, Heuristic Inquiry and Consensual Qualitative Research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying grounded theory to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: This capstone course involves the student developing and completing an original qualitative research project independent from the dissertation.

Independent research study allows the student to explore a topic of interest under the close supervision of a faculty member. The coursework may include directed readings, applied independent investigations - collaboration with a faculty member with a research project or carrying out an independent research project - and other activities deemed appropriate including grant proposal writing or programmatic evaluation work. Regardless of the nature of the experience, the work must culminate in a formal paper suitable for inclusion in a published research manuscript.

courseTitle: Research and Practice in Teacher Education
courseDescription: This course provides experiences that examine the theoretical and practical foundations of research and practice in teacher education. The course explores various facets of field- and university-based teacher education practices, which include but are not limited to school-university partnerships, mentor teaching and supervision of teacher candidates, and teaching education coursework. Students also consider the development of teacher educator identity, the benefits of collaborative inquiry, and research methods used to investigate teacher education learning and practice.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of teacher education learning and practice

courseDescription: This course provides students with an applied introduction to proposal and grant writing. Doctoral students who successfully complete the course will be prepared to seek external funding to support their continuing graduate studies and to support their future success as academics.

Explores topics related to the cultural characteristics of ethnically diverse populations and how these diverse populations and characteristics interact with social, political and economic institutions and the dominant culture to create the contemporary environment.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting respectfully with individuals of diverse backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing social, political and economic institutions
Understanding the dynamics of dominant culture

courseDescription: This course provides a guide through the process of academic writing, following practices for manuscript publication and dissertation writing. Peer feedback and individualized writing are hallmarks of the course. This course provides students with the knowledge and skills to become better academic writers through practice of successful strategies and habits related to the writing process as well as examinations of exemplars.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex ideas in writing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical examination of academic writing exemplars
Development and practice of successful writing strategies

courseDescription: Provides opportunities for doctoral students to explore topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.
Hours to be arranged. Provides opportunities for the doctoral student to do independent research in an area of his/her particular interests and needs.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Self-expression and communication of research findings

courseDescription: Preparation of dissertation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Staying in communication with academic advisor
Maintaining active participation in academic community
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and resolving academic standing issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-leadership for maintaining active student status
